step.reason: \text{For a function to be continuous at a\\ point it's limits on either side of f(x)\\ should be equal to the value of f(x) at\\ that point}

step.tex: f(x) \text{ is a straight line for }x\neq 2.\\ \text{Hence, it is continuous for all }x\neq 2.\\ \text{But we need to check for continuity \\ at x=2.}\\
step.reason: \text{At }x=2\text{, the definition of the function}\\ \text{changes. Hence, x = 2 could be the}\\ \text{only problem point. We should check}\\ \text{for continuity there.}

step.context: \text{Which of the following set of statements\\ are correct?}
step.tex:
\lim_{x\to 2^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 2^-} (2x+3) = 7 \\ \lim_{x\to 2^+}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 2^+} (2x-3) = 1 \\
f(2) = 2(2)+3 = 7\\ \\ \text{Hence, f(x) is discontinuous at x=2.}\\
step.reason: \text{Since, f(x) is continuous at x}\neq 2\text{(step 2)}\\ \therefore x=2\text{ is the only point of discontinuity.}

choices.tex: \text{Discontinuous everywhere in domain \\ of f(x) except x=2}
